channel.title: Item drop rarity
channel.description:
I don't think there's another section for this.. but if there is go ahead and move it there.
I want to make a drop table based on the rarity of each item an npc drop. The rarity goes from 0.00 (being basically impossible) to 1.00 (always).
What would be a good range to determine each rarity?
Example: 1 - 0.9 = Very Common 0.89 - 0.6 = Common 0.59 - 0.3 = Average 0.29 - 0.15 = Rare 0.14 - 0.07 = Very Rare 0.06 - 0.00 = Extremly Rare
But those are just an example. I don't think they would be very good.

item.title: Item drop rarity
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

[quote=“Cres, post:14, topic:549485”]Upon a kill, roll a random number ranging from 0 to 1. (only this part may need to be adjusted, because the value will actually range from 1/highest_estimated_kills to 1 in steps of 1/highest_estimated_kills.)
Loop through the list, comparing your random number to each “rarity” factor of each item.
If your rarity matches (is higher than the item’s rarity), get a list with all other items with the same rarity.
Return a random item from that list.
^ +/- how I’d do it[/quote]That isn’t mathematically accurate and makes your fractions completely useless…

Read full topic

item.title: Item drop rarity
item.dc:creator: @Cres Cres
item.description:
@Cres wrote:

Count the amount of drops listed for a specific NPC.
While parsing, remember what the highest “estimated_kills” value is and store that value along with the drops.
Sort the droplist from rarest to most common.

Upon a kill, roll a random number ranging from 0 to 1. (only this part may need to be adjusted, because the value will actually range from 1/highest_estimated_kills to 1 in steps of 1/highest_estimated_kills.)
Loop through the list, comparing your random number to each “rarity” factor of each item.
If your rarity matches (is higher than the item’s rarity), get a list with all other items with the same rarity.
Return a random item from that list.

^ +/- how I’d do it

Read full topic

item.title: Item drop rarity
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

[quote=“Cres, post:12, topic:549485”]that’s why you do
995 2/5
6727 1/32

the fractions don’t have to add up, but they give a better visual insight of what the rarity is[/quote]What? What if I wanted both of them to have the same rarity? How would I determine what the fraction should be? What if I have 3 items that I want to drop the same amount of times? What if I have 10 items? How would you do the rolls and figure out which item should drop? I don’t think you thought that idea through at all.

Read full topic

item.title: Item drop rarity
item.dc:creator: @Cres Cres
item.description:
@Cres wrote:

that’s why you do
995 2/5
6727 1/32

the fractions don’t have to add up, but they give a better visual insight of what the rarity is

Read full topic

item.title: Item drop rarity
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

[quote=“Cres, post:10, topic:549485”]I think a fraction for each drop individually is perfect.

drop amount/estimated_kills
995 2/5
so you can have it so that every 5 goblins you kill, you’re expected to get the coins drop twice

fractions don’t limit themselves to a range of 100 values
and 1/1 would represent a 100% drop

/thread tbh[/quote]
Ok, so what if I did
995 2/5
6272 2/5

I’m expected to get each drop twice? With that method you’re forced to either create a program or do a lot of math in your head to create the correct fractions.

Read full topic

item.title: Item drop rarity
item.dc:creator: @Cres Cres
item.description:
@Cres wrote:

I think a fraction for each drop individually is perfect.

drop amount/estimated_kills
995 2/5
so you can have it so that every 5 goblins you kill, you’re expected to get the coins drop twice

fractions don’t limit themselves to a range of 100 values
and 1/1 would represent a 100% drop

/thread tbh

Read full topic

item.title: Item drop rarity
item.dc:creator: @sinisoul sini
item.description:
@sinisoul wrote:

Cause it lacks transparency versus whole percentages.

Read full topic

item.title: Item drop rarity
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

[quote=“naseem142, post:6, topic:549485”]I think percentage chances would be better , you have a chance to get the item even if you did not kill let’s say 300 npc’s for a partyhat drop with a chance of 3%.
If you set it to get the drop at a specific kill amount it wouldn’t be the same…[/quote]
Again:
1.00 * 100 = 100%.
.9 * 100 = 90%
and so on…
I don’t see why my choice in number format is an issue.

Read full topic

item.title: Item drop rarity
item.dc:creator: @sinisoul sini
item.description:
@sinisoul wrote:

[quote=“naseem142, post:6, topic:549485”]I think percentage chances would be better , you have a chance to get the item even if you did not kill let’s say 300 npc’s for a partyhat drop with a chance of 3%.
If you set it to get the drop at a specific kill amount it wouldn’t be the same…[/quote]

That’s not what we’re saying…at all. That’s the expected rate, obvious if its random in smaller periods you’re not going to be exactly 3% or 50% but it will approach that % of chance over longer periods.

Read full topic

item.title: Item drop rarity
item.dc:creator: @naseem142 naseem142
item.description:
@naseem142 wrote:

I think percentage chances would be better , you have a chance to get the item even if you did not kill let’s say 300 npc’s for a partyhat drop with a chance of 3%.
If you set it to get the drop at a specific kill amount it wouldn’t be the same…

Read full topic

item.title: Item drop rarity
item.dc:creator: @eyeownyew Eyeownyew
item.description:
@eyeownyew wrote:

[quote=“sk8rdude461, post:4, topic:549485”][quote author=sinisoul link=topic=668387.msg4470128#msg4470128 date=1422511681]
Think it through. Obviously you want to control the rate at which each item is dropped to manage the available supply. If you take the average time to kill a creature, then factor that in with the drop rate you can come up with a figure of new stock/time. The factor of this is obviously a percent which represents rarity. There’s more you should take into account. It’s a good system but for terms of readability a number between 1-100 would suite best. I liked how jagex did it in their scripts with a subroutine for each case instead of a table so that they could integrate multiple drops.
[/quote]

1-100 is basically the system I have, just, * 100…
But I’m talking just taking the rarity based on the item’s drop rate, ignoring the monster and it’s features.[/quote]
like fractions is what he means
1/300 kills

Read full topic

item.title: Item drop rarity
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

sinisoul:

Think it through. Obviously you want to control the rate at which each item is dropped to manage the available supply. If you take the average time to kill a creature, then factor that in with the drop rate you can come up with a figure of new stock/time. The factor of this is obviously a percent which represents rarity. There’s more you should take into account. It’s a good system but for terms of readability a number between 1-100 would suite best. I liked how jagex did it in their scripts with a subroutine for each case instead of a table so that they could integrate multiple drops.

1-100 is basically the system I have, just, * 100…
But I’m talking just taking the rarity based on the item’s drop rate, ignoring the monster and it’s features.

Read full topic

item.title: Item drop rarity
item.dc:creator: @Clawz_fury lare69
item.description:
@Clawz_fury wrote:

this is what I use, and it works pretty well. extremely accurate to real RS https://github.com/lare96/asteria-3.0/blob/master/src/com/asteria/game/character/npc/drops/NpcDropChance.java

credits to Michael P

item.title: Item drop rarity
item.dc:creator: @sinisoul sini
item.description:
@sinisoul wrote:

Think it through. Obviously you want to control the rate at which each item is dropped to manage the available supply. If you take the average time to kill a creature, then factor that in with the drop rate you can come up with a figure of new stock/time. The factor of this is obviously a percent which represents rarity. There’s more you should take into account. It’s a good system but for terms of readability a number between 1-100 would suite best. I liked how jagex did it in their scripts with a subroutine for each case instead of a table so that they could integrate multiple drops.

Read full topic

I want to make a drop table based on the rarity of each item an npc drop. The rarity goes from 0.00 (being basically impossible) to 1.00 (always).

What would be a good range to determine each rarity?

Example:

0.29 - 0.15 = Rare
0.14 - 0.07 = Very Rare
0.06 - 0.00 = Extremly Rare

But those are just an example. I don’t think they would be very good.
